columns.text: In this problem,  we will solve for the payback period of the project.
The payback period refers to the amount of time it takes for the project to reach break even point.

In order to solve for the payback period, we must first solve for the annual sales for the product. To do this, simply multiply the estimated number of units by the sale price. 

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=155,000 \times \$535\\[15 pt]
&=\$82,925,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales in year 1 is $\$82,925,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=165,000 \times \$535\\[15 pt]
&=\$88,275,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales in year 2 is $\$88,275,000$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=125,000 \times \$535\\[15 pt]
&=\$66,875,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales in year 3 is $\$66,875,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=95,000 \times \$535\\[15 pt]
&=\$50,825,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales in year 4 is $\$50,825,000$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales}&=75,000 \times \$535\\[15 pt]
&=\$40,125,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales in year 5 is $\$40,125,000$

Next, we will solve for the lost sales in the first two years of the project. The lost sales refer to the lost revenue obtained when selling an item for cheaper value than the intended price. This can be solved by taking the difference in units sold for the current year and the lost in number of units sold if the newer model is not released. After that, this will be multiplied to the current sale price minus the sale price of the new model is not introduced.

For the lost sales, we can take the difference in the number of units sold in the first two years then multiply it by the price that the unit will be sold if the new model is not released. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Lost Sales}&=(95,000-65,000)\times \$385\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,550,000
\end{aligned}$$

If the new model is not released, then there will be $\$11,550,000$ worth of lost sales for the company.

We will then get the lost sales for **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Lost Revenue}&=(95,000-30,000)\times (\$385-\$215)\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,050,000
\end{aligned}$$

If the new model is not released, then there will be $\$11,050,000$ worth of lost revenue for the company.

We will then get the lost sales for **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Lost Revenue}&=(65,000-30,000)\times (\$385-\$215)\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,950,000
\end{aligned}$$

If the new model is not released, then there will be $\$5,950,000$ worth of lost revenue for the company.

Now that we have the lost sales for the first two years, we can now solve for the net sales. To do this, we can simply take the sales values in Steps 4 and 5 then subtract the lost sales and lost revenue.

For **Year 1**, the net sales is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net sales}&=\$82,925,000-\$11,550,000-\$11,050,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$60,325,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net sales for Year 1 is $\$60,325,000$

For **Year 2**, the net sales is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net sales}&=\$88,275,000-\$11,550,000-\$5,950,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$70,775,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net sales for Year 2 is $\$70,775,000$
The net sales for Year 3, 4, and 5 will be the same value as that in Steps 5-7, respectively, since there are no lost sales and revenue in these years.

Now, we will solve for the annual variable costs of producing the phones. To do this, multiply the estimated number of units sold by the variable cost. 

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable costs}&=155,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$34,100,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for the first year is $\$34,100,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable costs}&=165,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$36,300,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for the second year is $\$36,300,000$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable costs}&=125,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$27,500,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for the third year is $\$27,500,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable costs}&=95,000\times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$20,900,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for the fourth year is $\$20,900,000$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable costs}&=75,000\times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$16,500,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for the fifth year is $\$16,500,000$

Aside from the annual variable cost, we will also solve for the variable cost of the lost sales. We can do this by multiplying the difference in number of units sold in the first two years and the variable cost for the older model.\

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&= 30,000 \times \$145\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,350,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for the lost sales is $\$4,350,000$

Again, we will take the net variable cost for Years 1 and 2 by subtracting the annual variable cost and the variable cost for the lost sales. 

**Net variable cost for Year 1**
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net variable cost}&=\$34,100,000-\$4,350,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$29,750,000
\end{aligned}$$

**Net variable cost for Year 2**
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net variable cost}&=\$36,300,000-\$4,350,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$31,950,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net variable costs for Years 1 and 2 are $\$29,750,000$ and $\$31,950,000$, respectively. Again, the costs for Years 3 and 4 will remain untouched since there are no lost sales in those years.

Next, we will solve for the depreciation of the project. Depreciation refers to the amount of value lost per year throughout the lifespan of the asset. To do this, we will use the Modified Accelerated Cash Recovery System (MACRS). This is the method of computing the depreciation to determine a better valuation than the straigh-line method. Since we will be using a 7-year timeline, the factors are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.1429\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.2449\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1749\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.1249\\
\text{Year 5}&=0.0893
\end{aligned}$$

To solve for the depreciation, we will simply take the initial investment and multiply it by the corresponding factor in Step 23.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.1429\\[15 pt]
&=\$6,216,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 1 is $\$6,216,150$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.2449\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,653,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 2 is $\$10,653,150$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.1749\\[15 pt]
&=\$7,608,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 3 is $\$7,608,150$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.1249\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,433,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 4 is $\$5,433,150$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.0893\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,884,550
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 5 is $\$3,884,550$

For the next part, we will solve for the earnings and tax for each year. The earnings can be solved by subtracting the net variable cost, fixed cost, and depreciation from the net sales. Additionally, the tax can then be solved by multiplying the earnings by the tax rate.

To get the cash flow, we can simply take the earnings, add the depreciation, then subtract tax and net working capital cash flow. The net working capital is $20\%$ of the sales for that year.

For Year 1, our net cash flow is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net cash flow}&=\$17,958,850+\$6,216,150\\
&-\$3,771,358.50-(0.20 \times \$60,325,000)\\[15 pt]
&=\$8,338,641.50
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 3, our net cash flow is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net cash flow}&=\$25,366,850+\$7,608,150\\
&-\$5,327,038.50+\$780,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$27,427,961.50
\end{aligned}$$

Using the formula in Step 35, we can now solve for the payback period.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Payback period}&=2+\dfrac{\$43,500,000-\$8,338,641.50-\$25,762,911.50}{\$27,427,961.50}\\[15 pt]
&=2.343
\end{aligned}$$

The payback period for this investment is $2.343$ years.
